title: John Boehner on hot seat as Senate acts
content:
Boehner is following through on his promise to exhaust the legislative process . Boehner on hot seat as Senate acts
Long mired in bitter gridlock , two groups of Democratic and Republican lawmakers have hashed out once-unthinkable bipartisan solutions on gun control and rewriting the nation ’ s immigration laws .
But the rush to bipartisanship could grind to an abrupt halt in the House .
Speaker John Boehner is once again trapped in a tough position : If he doesn ’ t move on Senate-passed gun and immigration compromises , the House risks looking like it is obstructing the will of the American people . Should Boehner achieve consensus among Republicans on both issues , it could re-establish him as a deal maker and a central figure in upcoming legislative debates , while helping the House move on to more comfortable political and policy grounds .
Publicly , Boehner is being circumspect about how he ’ ll handle eventual gun and immigration legislation , promising to consider both issues if they pass the Senate — his aides are still skeptical they will . But behind the scenes , his team is planning , and GOP lawmakers are pushing him and Republican leaders in multiple directions .
Boehner is following through on his promise to exhaust the legislative process and will allow the House to decide whether to produce its own gun and immigration legislation .
All that makes the next few months — which will butt up against a debate on the nation ’ s borrowing cap and budget — one of the most active few months Washington has seen since 2011 .
“ It ’ s clear that the House Republicans have abdicated responsibility for legislation to the Senate , ” said Rep. Henry Waxman ( D-Calif. ) , a three-decade veteran of Washington . “ And [ the Senate is ] looking at trying to do things on a bipartisan basis , which is the only way to pass laws . I ’ ve seen very little in the House that shows they want to do anything on a bipartisan basis . ”
The House isn ’ t the Senate , and this pair of issues highlights the opposing pressure each chamber faces .
The reason the Senate found bipartisanship is complicated , and multifaceted , and includes political pressures such as senators posturing for presidential runs and the fact that House members must run for reelection every two years while senators face their constituents every six .
Wily Senate veterans like Lindsey Graham ( R-S.C. ) and John McCain ( R-Ariz. ) , who are cutting a deal on immigration , know how to navigate tough issues and have been trying to rewrite immigration laws for years . Sen. Chuck Schumer ( D-N.Y. ) is in a deal-cutting mood , with his eye on becoming majority leader . Sen. Jeff Flake ( R-Ariz. ) , a border-state lawmaker , was also just elected . Sen. Pat Toomey ( R-Pa. ) and Sen. Joe Manchin ( D-W.Va. ) , who cut the gun deal , don ’ t face voters until 2016 and 2018 , respectively .
House Republicans have taken a legislative back seat to the Senate purposely . Leadership has long been frustrated that its bills were ignored in the Senate . Boehner made the conscious decision to put pressure on Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid ( D-Nev. ) to take the lead in legislating — and he has .

Boehner is following through on his promise to exhaust the legislative process. Boehner on hot seat as Senate acts

The Senate has caught bipartisan fever.

Long mired in bitter gridlock, two groups of Democratic and Republican lawmakers have hashed out once-unthinkable bipartisan solutions on gun control and rewriting the nation’s immigration laws.

But the rush to bipartisanship could grind to an abrupt halt in the House.

Speaker John Boehner is once again trapped in a tough position: If he doesn’t move on Senate-passed gun and immigration compromises, the House risks looking like it is obstructing the will of the American people. Should Boehner achieve consensus among Republicans on both issues, it could re-establish him as a deal maker and a central figure in upcoming legislative debates, while helping the House move on to more comfortable political and policy grounds.

( Also on POLITICO: Can Gang of 8 stay tight?)

Publicly, Boehner is being circumspect about how he’ll handle eventual gun and immigration legislation, promising to consider both issues if they pass the Senate — his aides are still skeptical they will. But behind the scenes, his team is planning, and GOP lawmakers are pushing him and Republican leaders in multiple directions.

Boehner is following through on his promise to exhaust the legislative process and will allow the House to decide whether to produce its own gun and immigration legislation.

All that makes the next few months — which will butt up against a debate on the nation’s borrowing cap and budget — one of the most active few months Washington has seen since 2011.

( Also on POLITICO: 5 takeaways on Obama's budget)

“It’s clear that the House Republicans have abdicated responsibility for legislation to the Senate,” said Rep. Henry Waxman (D-Calif.), a three-decade veteran of Washington. “And [the Senate is] looking at trying to do things on a bipartisan basis, which is the only way to pass laws. I’ve seen very little in the House that shows they want to do anything on a bipartisan basis.”

The House isn’t the Senate, and this pair of issues highlights the opposing pressure each chamber faces.

The reason the Senate found bipartisanship is complicated, and multifaceted, and includes political pressures such as senators posturing for presidential runs and the fact that House members must run for reelection every two years while senators face their constituents every six.

( PHOTOS: What's in Obama's 2014 budget)

Wily Senate veterans like Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and John McCain (R-Ariz.), who are cutting a deal on immigration, know how to navigate tough issues and have been trying to rewrite immigration laws for years. Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) is in a deal-cutting mood, with his eye on becoming majority leader. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), a border-state lawmaker, was also just elected. Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.) and Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), who cut the gun deal, don’t face voters until 2016 and 2018, respectively.

House Republicans have taken a legislative back seat to the Senate purposely. Leadership has long been frustrated that its bills were ignored in the Senate. Boehner made the conscious decision to put pressure on Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) to take the lead in legislating — and he has.
